summary: This is a Federal Bureau of Prisons Program Statement (5270.09) establishing the Inmate Discipline Program, effective August 1, 2011. It outlines prohibited acts, sanctions, and the disciplinary process for inmates in BOP custody. The document is significant as it is the standard operating procedure for inmate discipline within the federal prison system at the time, but it contains no specific references to Jeffrey Epstein, his case, or any related individuals.

persons.name: Thomas R. Kane
persons.role: Acting Director, Federal Bureau of Prisons
persons.context: Approved the Inmate Discipline Program Statement (5270.09) as the Acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons.

events.title: Inmate Discipline Program Effective Date
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons Program Statement 5270.09, Inmate Discipline Program, becomes effective.

keyFacts: This is a generic Bureau of Prisons policy document on inmate discipline, not a case-specific record related to Jeffrey Epstein.
The policy establishes new prohibited act codes for sexual assault with force (Code 114) and without force (Code 229), reflecting updated BOP regulations.
It outlines the entire disciplinary process from incident report to investigation, Unit Discipline Committee (UDC) review, and Discipline Hearing Officer (DHO) hearing.
The document details sanctions including loss of good conduct time, disciplinary segregation, monetary fines, and loss of privileges.
It includes specific data entry instructions for tracking assaults and sexual offenses within the BOP's SENTRY system.
